questions.text: Which is correct regarding ectopic pregnancy?

options.label: A
options.text: The incidence of heterotopic pregnancy is decreasing due to early diagnosis

options.label: B
options.text: Atypical sites of ectopics are decreasing due to IVF

options.label: C
options.text: The incidence of an ectopic increases by about 50% following a history of ectopic

options.label: D
options.text: The relative incidence of ectopic pregnancy is increased with the use of intrauterine devices.

questions.correct_answer: D. The relative incidence of ectopic pregnancy is increased with the use of intrauterine devices.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let’s Discuss all the options:
  • • Let’s Discuss all the options:
  • • Option A: The incidence of heterotopic pregnancy is decreasing due to early diagnosis: This is incorrect. The incidence of heterotopic pregnancy is increasing due to increasing incidence of Assisted Reproductive Techniques. Option B: Atypical sites of ectopics are decreasing due to IVF: This is also incorrect. Atypical sites of ectopic pregnancy like cervical pregnancy, ovarian pregnancy etc. are increasing due to IVF Option C: The incidence of an ectopic increases by about 50% following a history of ectopic. This is also incorrect as the incidence of an ectopic pregnancy increases by 10-15% following a prior ectopic. Option D: The relative incidence of ectopic pregnancy is increased with the use of intrauterine devices. This is correct. With use of intra-uterine devices, the overall pregnancy rate is reduced but if a woman conceives with an IUD, it is important to note that the ectopic rate is high.

questions.text: A 24y lady presented to the emergency with generalized pain and spotting PV. Her LMP was 2 months back and she has a history of irregular cycles. On examination, she is pale, her PR is 110/ min, BP is 80/60 mmHg. There is guarding and rigidity on abdominal examination and a vaginal exam reveals cervical motion tenderness. Her urine pregnancy test is weakly positive. What is the next best step?

options.label: B
options.text: Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy

questions.correct_answer: B. Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is most likely a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. A RUPTURED ectopic pregnancy is a clinical diagnosis. Whenever there is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the patient in shock (hypotension, tachycardia), no time is to be wasted and the patient should be shifted to the OT for an emergency laparoscopy/ laparotomy and salpingectomy.
  • • This is most likely a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. A RUPTURED ectopic pregnancy is a clinical diagnosis.
  • • Whenever there is a ruptured ectopic pregnancy with the patient in shock (hypotension, tachycardia), no time is to be wasted and the patient should be shifted to the OT for an emergency laparoscopy/ laparotomy and salpingectomy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Dilatation and evacuation: This is not done in an ectopic pregnancy Option C: Doing an ultrasound (no matter how urgently in a patient with shock) will cause a delay and worsen patient prognosis Option D: Beta hCG (even urgent will take a few hours) is not indicated in a ruptured ectopic. It only has a role in an unruptured ectopic

questions.correct_answer: C. The level above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. The level above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized

questions.text: A 33-year woman comes to the OPD with amenorrhea of 6 weeks. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. A transvaginal ultrasound is done which shows normal uterus and adnexa. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Pregnancy of undetermined location

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This is a PREGNANCY OF UNKNOWN LOCATION (PUL): No sign of an intra or extra uterine pregnancy on ultrasound despite a positive pregnancy test
  • • Let’s discuss all the options:
  • • Let’s discuss all the options:
  • • Option A: Complete abortion: This is unlikely a complete abortion as there is no history of vaginal bleeding or passage of a tissue. Option B: Ectopic pregnancy: This could be a possibility but there is nothing in the scenario which is suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy Option C: Pregnancy of unknown location: This is what this scenario is. A pregnancy of unknown or undetermined location (PUL) means the urine or serum bhCG is positive but the ultrasound does not show an intra uterine or extra uterine gestational sac. Option D: Pseudocyesis: This is phantom pregnancy. In this the urine pregnancy test will be negative.

questions.text: The drug of choice for medical management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Methotrexate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The drug of choice for treatment of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is Methotrexate. MOA: Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase 2 protocols: Single dose and Multidose Usually, the single dose regime is sufficient, very rarely another dose is required.

It is commonly used in medical methods of termination of pregnancy along with misoprostol in 1 st and 2 nd trimester. Option C: Misoprostol: This is PGE1 and is a uterotonic. It induces uterine contractions and is therefore used in medical methods of termination of pregnancy, induction of labor and prophylaxis and management of atonic PPH. Option D: KCl: Ultrasound guided Intracardiac injection of Kcl is used in selective fetal termination in multifetal pregnancy reduction.

questions.text: A 24y old lady with a history of a tubal sterilization is diagnosed to have an unruptured ectopic pregnancy of size 4 cm. Serum βhCG is 6000 IU/L. The preferred management option is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Laparoscopic salpingectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This woman is not a candidate for medical management as the size is > 3.5 cm and βhCG is > 3000 IU/L. She requires surgical management: In an unruptured ectopic: Laparoscopy is preferred and, in this woman, a salpingectomy (removing the tube) is preferred to a salpingostomy (conserving the tube) as the patient has a h/o tubal ligation.
